utterances.speaker: WATTERS

And they are struggling in a lot of ways because Trump and his administration have been able to take away a lot of the arguments that Democrats have been making on the economy for years. So, wage increases for example were stagnant under Obama and for a couple years before that, they have gone up. The middle class has been bolstered. The tax cut actually did affect middle-class families more than the rich as the Democrats are saying. They are having a very hard time going into an election where racism being thrown, the wall is not working. The economy is something that people can gauge no matter who is in office and say are they working to make my life better? That's the argument Elizabeth Warren is trying to make and it's the argument that President Trump is trying to make. But for people to say that we need a recession to get Trump out is disgusting because it actually hurts people's welfare. It hurts their families. And it makes living really difficult. So I think they should be ashamed of themselves for continuing to push that. Having a recession is like saying there's going to be another sunset tomorrow. Of course, we always go into a new recession, but hoping for a political gain is pretty gross. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

The president, the week before the midterm elections in 2018 at a rally said, we have a big middle-class tax cut that is coming and he promised it. Then nobody ever talked about it again. And now they are starting to talk about it and I think they are trying to say what tools do we have. And a payroll tax cut doesn't help the rich. People who are actually working tough jobs, maybe two or three jobs, they are the ones paying the most payroll tax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: For the media, recession is like Beetlejuice. If you say it enough times, may be the monster will appear. I will -- I kind of disagree with you, Dana. I know. I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. Because -- and I think you will -- you and I both read a very important book by Robert Cialdini called "Influence."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We do know that a lot of the structures in our country are psychologically influenced. The media psychologically influences a lot of things and our markets are affected by optimism and fear. And Trump has benefited by an optimistic population. People are excited and they want to invest. If you can mess with optimism, you can mess with the markets. If you can instill fear, if you can instill the idea of -- with the police, they created this idea that all police were -- created brutality wherever they went. Doing it now with race, everybody is a racist. So, they can definitely influence our culture. I think they can influence the economy and I do think it's selfish because they are doing it because they just hate this guy. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } I remember when President Obama, under President Obama, Osama bin Laden was killed. I want a bad economy because I hate this guy. It's very selfish and you should be ashamed of yourself, Juan Williams. I just thought I would add that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Juan is so rich he can afford to ride out a recession.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This guy's made of money over here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, brand new details about the days leading up to Jeffrey Epstein's death -- what he did just two days before he hanged himself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Brand-new evidence in the Jeffrey Epstein case, it's raising this question. How long was he preparing to die? Court documents now obtained by Fox News show the convicted sex offender signed his will just two days before he killed himself in jail. The mysterious financier leaving behind an estate worth $600 million. This comes as Epstein lawyers are "not satisfied" with his autopsy results. The New York City medical examiner concluded that Epstein died by suicide from hanging. But Epstein's legal team, they say they plan to do their own independent investigation. Katie, does the fact that he was signing a will two days before he died, does that convince you this was suicide?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I'm not convinced of anything yet. I'm amazed that you can do this kind of business from prison, that you could turn over your will and get in touch with all the right people and make sure everything goes smoothly and find all the paperwork. But it does seem more logical that it was a suicide, considering it happened two days before and then he was taken off suicide watch two weeks prior to that. So the timeline of events and the pattern of behavior certainly suggest that. However, the lack of other evidence and transparency from the prison, still don't have video of what happened, no witnesses. I think a lot of that, there are still lots of questions about exactly what happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, the legal team says they still have doubts about the suicide conclusion coming from the autopsy, but they don't offer any reason. So what is going on?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think they have to offer a reason. I just think they just have doubts. But it is standard to knock out a well while you're holed up in confinement, while you have nothing else to do all day except talk to your lawyers. And he's sleek because the will, I guess, pours all the money into a trust so in a way it can protect it from lawsuits and things like that. The fine art, I guess, might be auctioned off so maybe people will get a chance to place a bid on the --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're going to bid on that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- Bill Clinton oil painting wearing the Lewinsky dress. We will see what that goes for. But my main concern here is it hanged or is it hung? What is the proper use of the word -- I would say he hung himself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, he hanged.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Everybody at the table said I'm an idiot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He hanged himself.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You know why Jesse? The word hanged is reserved for a person. The word hung is reserved for objects like picture frames.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not what Juan said in the break.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: That's the definition.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, so Dana, let's move along before we get in trouble. But you know what's interesting to me is now there's lots of talk about people who are tied into this. So, there is Ghislaine Maxwell, I think is how you pronounce it, and she was out in L.A. She got a picture in a burger joint. Now people are saying that was a set up to push the feds and the investigators off her trail. You have this man who was a model scout out in France and questions about his behavior and what he was doing, even possibly sending young women to Epstein in this country and then they ship her up. Do people tied into this case think that they are now scot-free or do you think that they have reason to worry?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I think that -- I think they are probably very worried because while Epstein was alive, there was a possibility that he could also talk about them, but all the focus was on him now that he's past. Then you have all of these people under the bright spotlight of the U.S. Attorney's Office or the federal prosecutor who basically are saying we are not going to give up on this which means that they -- because they are embarrassed, right. Epstein was under their charge, under the Bureau of Prisons. He is no longer here so the victims can't even have their day in court. He can't have his day in court. Now, he can't defend himself. And it's a $500 million estate, you know, with all of these lawyers and all of these things. Like, I don't know if there is going to be actually a victim's compensation fund and I'm skeptical about this will. He was supposedly, even though we don't know where all of his money came from, a financial planner. He was somebody who was advising people on finances. And I would like to know what his will said before the will that he signed on that day was because if you are that wealthy, I'm assuming you have some sort of a will, some sort of a financial plan. And he didn't have that. So, how he changed that at the last minute is curious to me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And Greg, do you think the prosecutors -- the prosecutors say they're going to continue their investigation despite the death. Do you trust that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I think -- I'm interested in the people that were accused by their primary accuser, Virginia --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Giuffre.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Giuffre? Giuffre. And I'm wondering like why isn't -- any of these powerful men who were like denying the suing, and it's because she has litigation privilege so, any accusations made in connection with court proceedings are immune from defamation actions, which seemed kind of interesting to me, like, what do you do in that case? So, they have to be accused in public in order for you to be able to sue them and whatnot. I'm interested in that, because like those are some pretty serious charges and nobody's really talking about that other than the people deny it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You mean - wait, so they cannot sue for defamation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It has to be done in public. It has to be a public slander, not in a court proceeding.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, you're talking about other men who have been accused of--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. George Mitchell's, Georgia (ph), Richardson, the people that were named.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But they say that nothing happened.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nothing happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But they now can't sue her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, they can't sue her unless if she slanders. If she accuses them publicly behind a court proceeding. I'm not a legal expert. How did I get here, and it is hanged?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But by the way, do you think that the Feds are really going to pursue this, or do you think that this is just going to blow away like you know with the fall winds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, it is about a will. William Jefferson Clinton.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Where there is a will?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There is a - what.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you know probably the reason that he may not have planned an extensive will is because he didn't have a wife, he didn't have children usually that, if you have that that might.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Motivate you to make those plans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think the whole thing about wealth management is about figuring out a way to deal with taxes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but remember what you said.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We don't know how he got his money. To this moment--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It is a puzzle. This guy out in Ohio who owns Victoria's Secret.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wexner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Les Wexner. How can you say, yes, I meant to mention he stole millions from me? I mean how does that happen. PAVLICH: Well, to your question Juan about whether federal prosecutors are going to continue to pursue this. They clearly have been because they went to the island, they've got more evidence even though it has been changed. There are big questions about that. But the victims that were in the lawsuits that have been filed that were filed before Epstein died got the phone call that the indictment has been dismissed because when the person dies, the indictment is dismissed on Jeffrey Epstein.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Now, if they find other enough evidence to indict other people then they will bring charges and prosecution. But you have to remember how long this took for them to get Jeffrey Epstein on an indictment with all the proof, because the bar for proof is very high.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, give me a date for the case.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I can't give a day.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It could be years.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It could be years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Really long time. And one of the things that some of the lawyers are recommending is, like we've had in the past - in the recent past, a victim's compensation fund.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But that means that people have to agree to be a part of that and that could take forever. PAVLICH: They say to go to a trial, right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, see I was hoping that you would get a case whereas Greg was saying, you could have everything in court. Everybody could say this is transparent. We know what happened now, but that doesn't seem to be the case. It doesn't seem like that's in anywhere near taking place. And I think politically Jesse, this is not about any one party, but it could damage people who are in-charge and you know which administration is in-charge at the moment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, but who scrub the server.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A dangerous new trend landing dozens of teens in the hospital and now, the CDC, the disease control folks they've launched an investigation. The details behind this next on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: A popular trend among teens is being blamed for putting almost 100 people in the hospital across the country. Some of the patients say, vaping gave them severe respiratory problems, but doctors haven't been able to figure out the specific cause. So, now the CDC is getting involved to investigate the potential link between electronic cigarettes and these mysterious lung diseases. The symptoms ranging from shortness of breath to extreme examples like this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're having a heart attack.

utterances.speaker: AMMIRATA
utterances.sentences: Like I was having a heart attack. I just freaked out and they said your lung has collapsed. You have to go to surgery right now.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: These are people who vape, but they are not conclusive on whether vaping is the cause of these symptoms that they're saying. GUTFELD: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Do you have some opinions on vaping?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It could be what type of product they're using. It could be the THC and the media loves stuff like find something go, disturbing trend, but we have to remember this and it bears repeating that vaping existed 50 years ago, a lot of our relatives would be alive right now because vaping is nicotine without the tar and it's the tar that kills people. So, people do get injured from airbags. Right. But airbags save lives. So, you've got to weigh the benefits and the risk. Vaping is pretty new, so maybe they will find out that there is stuffs that's wrong with it. But I would like to think that this is saving lives and I think it's getting - it got me to quit smoking. I mean - I moved on to vaping and then I didn't even smoke anymore. I don't even vape anymore. Basically, I just sit by myself. PAVLICH: So, Dana, it seems like - just sit by yourself, yes. Teenagers are using this as not to quit smoking, but as like a fun and--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A lot of it--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Cool habit, it's cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. And a lot of the cases where there have been problems have been younger people like the young man that we just heard from there. Also, and I don't know about his case in particular, but some are adding things into the vape.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, THC or some sort of additional thing that Dr. Siegel was talking about today called acetol. They're not exactly sure what it is, and it could also be as Dr. Siegel said maybe an allergy to those particular products and those things. What I'm concerned about is that adults should not be barred from being able to buy a product like this, because teenagers abuse it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's not the way that we should do things.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Jesse, do we need more government regulation on jewels and other e-cigarettes. WATTERS: Yes, they're probably going to tell them don't target kids with the marshmallow flavor.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They already did that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Watermelon.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Marijuana flavor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think that's a good thing and then they've stopped. But listen, I act like a teen because I skipped smoking cigarettes and I went straight to the Jewel and I did it all last summer and then I kicked it. It's not that hard to quit. And Greg's right. It's much better than actual tobacco, because that stuff will kill you. So, this is just kind of like a smooth off ramp from that. But you know, it's not good for you. They don't think it's great for you, but as the studies will show probably in 10 years, you know it couldn't be that good for your lungs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Juan, the CDC is looking into this. They're working with a number of local health departments in California, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota, Wisconsin. The FDA is also investigating. 127 reports of seizures after vaping. So, when big companies who are selling these products that people under 18 can buy oftentimes as we know Washington D.C. comes knocking on the door. Do you think that they're going to be holding hearings about some of these problems they say that are connected to vaping? WILLIAMS: Of course. And Jewel is already backed off what Jesse was talking about, the flavored smoke so that people can you know - especially for kids. They say oh it's just like its candy, it's fun. They - Jewel no longer sells those, but other people that have come into the marketplace to sell the flavored smokes. My point and I think you know my retort to all that you're saying is, it still contains nicotine which is highly addictive. And so--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, is love, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you. Tell Marianne, your pal Marianne about this. And so, it may be as you say oh it's a less dangerous than smoking a cigarette. But it doesn't mean it's not dangerous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, it's way less.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And it certainly doesn't mean that not addictive. So, to my mind, they market this as a safe alternative. In my mind that is nonsense. And that is again a way to draw people into get them attracted, get them hooked on--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Typical blaming the jewels.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, the jewels, the family jewels to blame.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what it is?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jewels, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is the consequences to freedom. We know if we inhibit freedom it's going have the opposite effect, right. People like to smoke cigarettes when you were told you couldn't smoke cigarettes and the drug war hasn't done anything really other than jail people who are seeking relief. So, what are we going to do, you just tell your kids to knock it off and they're going to do it? You see where it goes. I think what Dr. Siegel said that I thought was really interesting was when he talked about that because the behavior is spreading, you're going to find a pocket--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're going to find more people that have - are allergic to it. Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, if all of a sudden you know they invent peanut butter and everybody is eating it, then you find out that people are allergic to peanut butter and let's not forget that sometimes better technology gets a bum rap. For example, why do we have blimps, but we don't have Zeppelins, right. Because Zeppelin's, the Hindenburg - Hindenburg, they had one event, no more zeppelins also one is helium and one is hydrogen I believe. PAVLICH: OK. So, Dana--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But we still have cigarettes. We still - I mean I smoke cigars.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We still have these things Greg, it's not that they are illegal.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Worse than a Jewel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I don't think - but the thing is when you say to a kid you know what cigarettes are not hip, they're in movies. But you know what, it's bad for your health.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's why--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They were being told oh no jewels aren't as bad. Try this. That's wrong.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think that--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Nobody should be doing this. PERINO: Peer pressure is something but also, I feel the same way. I'm not susceptible to celebrity endorsements or comments. But younger people can be. And if some celebrity that these young people admire says that's - you look dumb when you do that. I wouldn't be vaping if I were you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I remember the ad with Steve - who was selling vaping, it was Stephen Dorff, it was a commercial with Stephen Dorff. That does not sell vaping.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: No, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, Juan's celebrity and if he says no smoking, the jewel, you better listen to Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But he smokes cigars, which is worse than smoking to Jewel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Typical hypocrite.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Let us live everybody. WILLIAMS: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Anyway. Up next, the most annoying thing co-workers do to get on your nerves.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Every office has one, the chatty co-worker who doesn't realize or care how busy you are. Instead they just keep talking about their weekend or favorite TV show, The Bachelor. Well, now there are scientific research that shows that if this sets you off, you're not alone. A new study says most people find over talkative co-workers to be the biggest workplace distraction. Greg, do you have any experience with this?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, let me tell you something, we often complain about smokers but at least smokers go outside the building and don't bother you, right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, because they've been banished.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. But it's not about - OK, it's not about talking about work. We're now in these open plan situations and I have office privilege, we all have offices, but there's an open plan for everybody. Work talk assimilates into the environment like it just tunes out, right. You don't hear it--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What's in the A block.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the non-work conversations that get into your heart and soul and make you murderous inside because it doesn't assimilate. So, you're working and the person next to you like, I've just got a rescue dog. Oh, you've got to see pictures of my rescue dog--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Are you talking about the person next to you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I was talking about--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: In general.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I am using examples of people who don't work here anymore. But they're like or I'm going to see this band, and they start talking about this crap and you're like - going like I'm working.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, you know what's going on here. This is someone on my staff who sits outside of Greg's office.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. You've been talking about this for two weeks.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are so bad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There is someone that has been driving Greg crazy because maybe there is a concern that he or she went to and everybody knows about it. And do I have to discipline this person because Greg's annoyed or do I like the fact that Greg's annoyed, he gives us good content. GUTFELD: I can't believe you did that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, regardless of that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You did it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think all the plans are not a good idea for the workplace. I don't think they're good. But also, if you have over talkative co-worker and they are negative about the company, you have to separate yourself from that. PAVLICH: Yes, definitely. Because if you don't respond, they notice, but if you do respond, it can make you look bad and you just sit and engage. But the open concept thing was like this good idea for everyone to be creative and talk to each other and every survey they take about open concepts, everybody hates it because they can't get any work done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You feel distracted.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, now--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: There is privacy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Everybody gets an office now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan, you like it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: They thought that was a great idea.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I do like it. And I've got to say, I had a T-shirt. I love T- shirts and I had a T-shirt that said Cool Story Bro. And my daughter had to tell me that's an - I was telling people to shut up and let you do your thing. I was like I didn't realize it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I didn't know that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I didn't either. But in response to all I'm hearing I think this. We're not robots. We should not be silent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are you sure?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I hope not, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is a simulation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I think ideas come from good conversation and you want to know, I want to know if Jesse's having an issue, so I can say OK, well Jesse is going to be in the pits today. He's not in the mood.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse has no issues.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You never come down and talk to me, Juan. What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But office gossip is currency brother.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's very important that we know what's going on among us, in the company. PERINO: You know the worst thing about open plan are the notifications of emails that are coming in. That's--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You don't like the ding, ding, ding.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Ding, ding.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And people talking on the phone. PERINO: You're right at your computer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but Dana, you have a nice corner office that separated from everybody else on the floor. You don't hear a lot of ding, ding, ding. The ding, ding, ding you hear is the cash register. WILLIAMS: Whoa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Whoa. What I like to do is I like to close my door and have fictitious loud threatening conversations on my phone that everybody can hear and then ended with, good day talking to you Mr. Murdoch. Then I walk out, and everybody changes, everybody's like, wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They're like, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What did you take before the show? GUTFELD: It was another show.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. One More Thing is up next. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Whatever. One More Thing, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. It's time to school to start up again. You know I love back to school and so does this little girl here six-years-old, Ariana. Watch her.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bye, Ariana. Have a good day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. She is six-years-old, when she was two-years-old, she was diagnosed with cerebral palsy. Her father says she loves school because she gets so much positive attention from classmates and is very interactive. She loved it and the bus drivers were excited to have her on there. So, good luck to you, Ariana.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's do this. Animals Are Great. All right. Let's go to China, shall we? This is such a beautiful story. You're going to check out this little furry guy. See this little furry guy, notices his other furry fellow, small dog drifting downstream in a rowing boat, perhaps in grave danger. The dog is trying to figure out what to do when he sees the rope. He says you know what, I'm going to go out there and get my friend and save him. And he pulls the little guy in and saves the dog's life. And they both made a lovely meal. Together.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Look at that. Very cool.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And that is why, Animal Are Great.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Smart dog.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dogs helping out dogs, Dana. PERINO: I love that. Those are great, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. You didn't mean that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. You've heard the phrase Touched by An Angel. Well, take a look at this video because it looks like heaven sent help.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's Romulus McNeill. He barely escaped death when that bolt of lightning hit inches from them as he walked to his car in South Carolina. He said all he felt was a rush of static and dropped the umbrella. He had no idea what was coming. What really makes this incredible to me is McNeill had just stepped in water, had keys in one hand and umbrella in the other and a cell phone in his pocket. All of that could have brought the lightning current right to him. By the way you should know 12 people, 12 Americans have died from lightning since May. Most of the men, Romulus says, he was saved by an angel. And after watching that, I think he's right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's scary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right then, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, do you consider diving a sport?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What about belly flopping?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because belly flopping is a sport in Norway. Check out these guys. Right here. Ready. So, he's kind of like hold the position that exposes yourself way up into the last second. You can kind of come through in Norwegian. This is called Dodson. I've never tried it nor never will try it except maybe tonight on Hannity if I flopped big time. But I never do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We should buy Norway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We should. You know why?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're doing with water.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: For half price, two for one.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I will say as a diver for many years, it is a sport.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Jesse, this part.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, Katie. Take it out.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right. So, there was a family in Northern California over the weekend who had an unexpected visitor at their house. Greg, you want to avoid this at your lake house. It was a black bear looking for a midnight snack in the Sherman family's kitchen in Cherokee, California, north of Lake Tahoe. Teenagers in the house heard the refrigerator beeping, so they went downstairs and saw the bear rummaging around the cupboards. They called the cops right away and where you knew it, the local sheriff's department stopped by to let the bear out of the house and took a picture with the two boys.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh! My Gosh.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, pretty crazy that bears can get in your house. But actually, growing up, there that's bear in our neighborhood. He went through a doggy door and was eating the dog food in someone's kitchen. GUTFELD: I think that's just a naked Alec Baldwin.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Katie, did he open the fridge.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: He opened the fridge. Yes. Bears are smart. They have hands.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I accuse of up to 180.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But how did he know that there was food in the fridge.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Because he could smell it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes, they're smart.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Well that was exciting. Again, we end with a bear. And we leave it to a 'Baier.' Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five."
